Wat nu het verschil is tussen Porter en Stout werd niet meteen duidelijk na het drinken van dit biertje. De geur was er een van drop en zoethout, de smaak was puur gebrande mout. Niet mis, maar de oxidatie voorkwam dat dit bier écht goed te noemen kon worden.

On tap at Church Key in San Francisco.  Pours an opaque darkest brown or black color with minimal head.  The aroma is roasty with dark chocolate, anise, and mint.  The flavor is nice but not too full.  A fair amount of malt sweetness, dark chocolate, lots of roast, and mint.  Flat on the mouthfeel with medium-full body.  I did not like the lack of carbonation much.  A tasty beer, but falls a little short in a fullness of flavor and mouthfeel.

10 ounce goblet - $9.00 at Taco Mac in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Passed along to me a body colored black and topped off with a foamy, khaki-hued head.

Smell: Dark, particularly roasty maltiness yielding fragrant notes of conspicuously charred barley, espresso powder, smokey charcoal briquettes, prune juice, and black licorice, though only a hint of dark chocolate.

Taste: A start of pungent roasted grains, modestly sweet, and with tastes featuring bittersweet chocolate and rudely burnt coffee. Minor dark fruitiness. From top to bottom, its fairly roasty with a light astringency to it. The black jelly bean licorice character is building and becomes a bit tiring. Very small hint fo woodiness. Some hop bitterness and acidity showing on the otherwise roasty finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Reasonably smooth mouthfeel.

Drinkability: As with Korean cuisine, Im likin it, but Im just not lovin it. Still, Id say give it a try, as most everyone else seems to be diggin it.

Pours a typical dark brown color. Minimal head. No Lacing.

Aroma is nice - has everything youd expect from a good porter, but also some other interesting notes that I cant quite pin down. Flavor is a bit more standard. Roasted malts dominate with just a smidge of some bitter chocolate and coffee coming through. Lighter side of medium bodied and carbonation seems just right for the body.

Have to say Im slightly let down by this. Its decent, but if I want a porter Edmund Fitzgerald is still my go to... glad I tried this one though.

On tap at Rattle N Hum.  Pours a deep black to brown with a medium to large tanned beige head.  Toast and roast on the nose, light coffee.  Nice roast and plum character.  Smooth chocolate.  Clean and well done, though a touch thin.  Long malt, toast, and chocolate on the finish.
On tap at rattle in hummers.   Roasted malts and espresso.   Some vanilla tones, delicious.

head: dark beige , normal 
colour: black 
smell: candy sugar , maple syrup , red fruits , burned malts, some liquour , bit of coffee 
taste : bitter malty start , some sourness in background,  some alcohol , biterness again but more of a coffee bitterness this time ... no taste of coffee tough !( i mean not clearly coffee like u can have with imp stouts .. )  more earthy ... grassy , bit hopy , end is dry ... a great beer altough i think it would be better if it had some more punch in it .. not so thin ... anyway great !

Bottle: Literally black, medium-sized stable & lacy tanned head; solid fruity-port-vinous nose (but not really sweet!) with a robust roasty and chocolatey backbone; medium to full bodied, silky MF; moderate to robust bitter and also a bit sweet flavour; dry roasty and light sweet malty finish with a subtle fruity touch. Very good.....
Bottle. Aroma of roasted malt and dark chocolate. Very dark brown colour with light brown head. Malt flavour with som dark bitter chocolate and a hint of tobacco. Soft mouthfeel.

(bottle) Almost black coloured hue with a light-brown and thick foamy head. Roasty malty and chocolatey aroma combined with a touch of liquorice and a slightly fruity-vinous and minimal piney hoppy touch. Roasty bitter flavour, medium to full bodied with a silky mouthfeel. Robust roasty malty taste with notes of dark chocolate, tabacco and tar; dry and roasty bitter and very lasting finish with a cornucopia of flavours in the aftertaste. 22.VI.10
Poured black with a creamy light brown head. Pleasant aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, licorice, and a little nuttiness. Mildly sweet with just a bit of bitterness.

Bottle (50 cl), brewed 18/08/08,
Pitch black, with an off-white head.
Aroma of chocolate, caramel and some roasted malts.
Taste is dark chocolate with hints of caramel and coffee.
Dry, slightly roasted / bitter finish. 
Very pleasant indeed.

0,5 l bottle from CrackedKettle, courtesy of Balazs, thx a lot;-)
Poured black like rock-oil, small foamy tan head that melts to a small lacing one. Firstly a fruity aroma opens with raisins and caramel. Mild spicy notes with clove, vanilla. After a while the espresso, coffee and peat rules the aroma. Medium, airy body, mild oily density. Roasted grains and burnt wood, dark chocolate and coffee, cocoa. Peat and burnt aftertaste with some toasted nuts. Fine!
Sampled in a 22oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a thin brown head on it. Very quality malts. Palate is good but a bit interesting and overall a really nice brew.

Poured black with an off-white, lacing head. Nice aroma of licorice, roasted malts, coffee, burnt wood and hops. Becomes fruity as it warms up with plums, raisins. Medium dense with low carbonation, but still strong on the palate. Sweet taste, with hoppy, dry aftertaste. Very nice.

Kind of a last minute decission to have this here brew. I just wanted something new and something to rate, raded the stash and saw this lurking, and thought why not. It may be 26 degrees C and humid, but Im no seasonal drinker. Anyhow, the beer: Pours very dark red/brown-black with a beige dese head, nice and creamy looking. The aroma is an interesting, but lovely blend of sweet and savoury characteristics. The first whiff reveals a dusty nose, but underneath you have aromas of salty black olives, blackberry and a sweetness I cant quite place, a lighter berry... perhaps cherry or raspberry. I have to add though, the aroma is not massively forthcoming, and seems a little subdued. The flavour is once again subtle, but consists of notes of darker chocolate, some coffee-ishness, dry dates, charcoal, ash and an earthiness not far off black olives, but also reminds me a little of burnt toast. The flavour succeeds in being neither sweet or bitter, its very well balanced, however, it is dry. The finish is a little abrupt leaving you with a slight warmth, fruit, cream and dust. Mouth feel is surprisingly creamy and soft, and also mid-full bodied, which I wasnt expecting as it looked a lot thinner when being poured, than it feels on the palate. At the end of the day, this is nothing radical, but it is a very well made Porter with everything you would expect from this type of beer brewed in Scandanavia; so whilst it hasnt rocked my world, its another big thumbs up for the Nogne Brewery and their skills.

500mL Bottle, purchased at Wakefield Liquors - Wakefield, RI. Theres something about Nogne that always comes across as Boreal, coniferous, and juniper-like to me. The aroma and flavor profiles all seem to have a similar piney-edge that I really enjoy. This example is no different. With a crisp, clean cool ocean scent of salicornium, agarwood, and earth. A dense brown-black pour with copious creamy tan head. Flavors are vibrant, prickly, and dense. Lots of robust roasted qualities and a flourishing hoppiness that mingles with an English yeast for a complex addition to the already deep maltiness. Clean, tight, concise and together. Nice work.

500 ml bottle from Ludlow Wines.  I thought it was on sale when I bought it, but it just happened to be on the rack of winter/Christmas beers and didnt qualify.  So I wound up with it anyway.  Not a bad predicament to be in, since this is a pretty nice beer.  Pours an opaque dark brown with a small brown head with good retention.  Aroma of chocolate, dark fruits, caramel malts, hops, yeast, and mineral notes.  Flavor of chocolate and caramel malts, dark fruits (some tart), earthy hops, mineral and metallic notes, and dry milk powder.  Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a malty mouthfeel.  Dry, roasty finish.  Very good porter.
was expecting much more from this beer.  pretty thin and metallic mostly with a swirl of caramel and alcohol and nuttiness.  just doesnt hold together though.

I saw this on sale for $8 when it had been $10 so I bought it despite the fact that it still was a pretty bad deal for a 500ml bottle of porter. It was black of course and smelled a little roasty but also a tinge of metallic so I knocked the score down. The taste was nice, sweet, roasty, pretty good. I will of course never buy a second bottle because it is just to expensive but this was a pretty good American porter with a robust flavor.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-01-2010 14:29:48

Pretty much dead on for my mental picture of a strong porter.  Great chalky roast character that, for me, is the signature of the style.  Dark, bitter chocolate combines with bready malt, light caramel and mild English yeast.  Relatively big bitter citric hops push through, despite the relatively low IBU count and at least four or five months of age on the bottle.  Theres a licorice flavor in there, too - no idea what thats from.  Dry flavor.  The beer looks great.  Its black with a big head, creamy and light brown.  Mouthfeel could be a touch fuller, but its quite good.  Excellent porter with great bitterness.

Bomber. Black with off white medium head. Aroma of roasted milk chocolate, light coffee bean, darker breads, berry fruit covered in chocolate. Taste is semi sweet chocolate into a bitter roastedness. Some darker fruit notes in flavor. Light to medium bodied with good carbonation.

Beige head atop a black brew, aroma is very roasty and malty, milky. Flavor is the same, chewy, roasty and chalky. No sweetness with mild bitterness. Pretty dry in the palate. Bottle from Stop and Shop, Miami.

Tap at Brasserie V in a flight with #100 and the IPA - Pours dark and murky, with a nice foamy tan head thats gone quickly. Smells of medium roast malt with nice, light smoke and a bit of lactose. Taste is smooth and roasty--nice bitter roast flavors mix with dark chocolate and smoke on the finish. Its medium-bodied, though a bit watery, and very smooth. My favorite of the three Nogne beers I tried, though the IPA was close.

0,5 l bottle @ Cardinal. Pours black with a decent light brown head. Excellent lacing. Pleasant and inviting aroma of milky coffee and roasted malts. Flavors and mouthfeel deliver on the aroma. Tastes sweet with a burnt bitterness. Nice coffee in the finish and also hops character. Alcohol is there but its all well balanced. Medium-full bodied and smooth as milk.
Fantastic beer.
UPDATED: JUN 11, 2010 50cl, Norwegian brewery, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex Porter, yet easy to drink, balanced, hazy, good head, good brew

On draft at The Belgian Cafe, Philadelphia. Medium-sized tan head over dark brown beer. Coffee aroma. Coffee and chocolate flavors. Mildly bitter. A little too thin-bodied for my taste, but still easily drinkable.

500mL bottle.  Pours opaque black with a light brown head.  Slightly hoppy aroma of roast, coffee and chocolate.  Flavour much the same without the hops.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation with a roasty, slightly astringent finish.

500 mL bottle tasted blind on 3/11/10.  pours dark brown with nice tan head. Great aroma of coffee, chocolate, pine and grass.  Flavor was really roasty and tasted like burnt caramel (good thing).  Very dry mouthfeel and finish and good carb.  Extremely drinkable.

16.9oz bottle, pours out black with a HUGE tan head that lasts forever.  Strong scent of coffee and dried fruits, starts with a coffee taste which turns to chocolate and leads to a creamy chocolate aftertaste.  A fine porter.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2014 This porter from Nøgne Ø rests comfortably in my snifter glass, its near-black body flaunting a thick, dense medium tanned head with a certain amount of stayer in it. Looks good. Smells just as nice, a bit of toast, hints of sour yeast and strong overtures of chocolate. Taste is a bit of toffee and mild coffee notes. Short aftertaste, and I had actually expected a bit more on that part. Palate is decent and alcohol is extremely well hidden, making this a very drinkable porter. Nøgne Ø may not quite reach to the top with this one, but its certainly a well decent brew.
22 oz Bottle -- Pours black with a small light tan head.  Aromas of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, raisin, and some smoke.  Silky smooth yet rich palate, mild bitterness.

@ a tasting, pours black with some red taints and creamy tan head, aroma of caramel, oak, whiskey, cherries, vanilla and butter, flavor is smokey like charcoal and cigar with some espresso notes. Medium bodied. Nice

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks zvikar. Black-colored with a big light brown head. Aroma of sweet chocolate, a light roasty character and some fruity notes. Flavor starts sweetish with chocolate, some smoky wood hints, notes of nuts and a bitter, slightly herbal, finish. Medium to full-bodied. A nice Porter.

At a tasting, thanks Zvikar, small stable beige head, opaque extremely dark brown colour, aromas of coffee, roasted malt and some barnyard notes, flavours of coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt,  a touch of barnyard and some hops coming later, quite dry.  long roasted aftertaste with a little dryish sensation in the end. excellent porter.
Bottle at a tasting: mocca, cocca butter, lots of semi sweet/mild bitter chocolate, some honey, dry finish, great porter, better then the imperial stout.

No identifying dates/batches on bottle.
Huge head. Bottle was unshaken and still once the cap was popped, the head just crept up. Pours dark with a huge light tan head. Cannot properly describe the aroma; it is not sweet, not roasted, not burnt. Will have to update when I find the words to describe it. Does not taste like a typical porter, the fruit undercurrent covers the porter taste. Starts out tasting like a dark fruit, and finishes with a light porter taste. Almost creamy texture. Overall, I was expecting a porter however I got an experience instead. This is a great beer to ease people into darker beer.
Not much aroma, but does have a subtle smell of alcohol and dark camelized fruit.  Taste of strong bitter coffee and baking chocolate. Moderate astringent finish.
2007 bottle.  Poured jet black with thin tan head.  Smelled of smoky and dark chocolate, and taste starts bitter chocolate and moves into sweeter with the dark fruit.  Very good porter!
Great beer.  Very dark pour with a small head.  Tastes of a little coffee and chocolate.

chocolate with a deep sweetness and touch of vanilla. dried fruits evident with a hint of almond. busy beer makes it seem thicker than it is but this is only somewhat thicke in the palate. deep flavor overall this brew lingers and reveals some roastiness. some earth and a frothy and lasting head. you get what you pay for.....sometimes.

Bottle. 22 oz. Split with Sean. Pours rich chicory brown, almost opaque with a thick, frothy amber head. Aroma of chocolate, brown sugar, toffee, barley, roasted malts, and hints of clove. Awesome body; coca-cola complexity and a crisp, yet slowly smooth finish. Hands down, best porter I have ever tasted. Absolutely excellent.

(bottle - 500 ml) Dark black pour with a creamy tan head. Aroma is heavy roasted malts with a lot of coffee aroma as well. Flavor begins with a roasted and slightly sweet malt taste that goes smoothly to a roasted and burnt malt/coffee middle. Finishes strong with a heavy roast and bitter note. Hops are subdued and the body is smooth and silky. Aftertaste is bitter and lingers for a bit. Nice porter.

Sweet bitter taste of choclate, coffee, dried fruit. And a aftertaste of burned caramel.
Beautiful aroma of coffee and sugar.
Lovely design and appearance.
Dark mahogany pour with tan head. Aroma of alcohol and chocolate malt. Tastes of chocolate and caramel malt with vanilla, roasted bitterness on the finish. Great creamy mouthfeel.

Dark brown with a small ligth brown head. Aroma is of light roasted malt, toffe and light caramell with small hoppy notes. Flavour is rather full, very smooth and round with light roasted chocolatey malt, creamy caramell and light hops proper for the style. Smooth bodied and slightly creamy. A very solid porter.
Tap at Capones.  Pours a deep brown with a medium creamy tan head that laced.  Aroma of caramel, chocolate, tobacco, leather and coffee.  Flavor of the same with hints of cherry.

Draught at Capones:  Aroma of chocolate, malts, and caramel.  Poured pitch black in color with a large, creamy, dense, rocky, brown head that lasted throughout.  Great looking head.  Opaque.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is medium sweet and slightly bitter.  tastes of chocolate, roasted malt, light caramel, and light maple syrup.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Soft carbonation.  Roasted malt and chocolate finish is dry.  A very nice porter.

1pt 9oz bottle.  Pours a very dark brown color with a rich dense light brown head.  The smell is roasted coffee beans with hints of chocolate and caramel.  Flavors of roasted coffee, bittersweet chocolate, dried flowers, earthy hops, bready malt, and dark fruit.  A well balanced beer where the alcohol is well hidden.  Medium bodied and very smooth with a nice slightly dry finish.

Pours very dark brown, but not completely black, with a medium tan head.  Aroma is of coffee and roasted malt with a touch of caramel.  Nice coffee flavor mixed with sweet caramel and fruit.  Medium body.  This is an excellent porter, and definitely something I will be buying again.

A good traditional Porter. Reminds me of meantime london porter (this is better) and tokyo black (nogne is probably not as good). Lots of chocolate and coffee notes, though slightly thin on the palate. Well made but not jaw dropping.

Nøgne Ø Porter is a dim, dark brown ale with a thin, dense, beige head that leaves excellent lacing on the glass.  It smells dark and complex, with a lot of roasty coffee.  Its medium bodied, smooth and clean in the mouth.  Its not sweet.  The flavor is well balanced and roasty like coffee.  There are notes of dark chocolate and cassis.  For some reason, I was expecting a Baltic Porter, but this is more bitter and complex.  This is a delicious beer.

Had this at Puck Fair and irish Bar in NYC.  I just started a novel by Norwegian author so decided to celebrate with a beer from Norway.  really good beer, good coffee favor and some smoke, pretty much liked everything about it

Dark, dark brown pour with a light tan head, moderately good retention and lacing.  Aroma is sweet roasted grain, coffee, and a bit of chocolate.  Flavors of coffee and roasted malt with a semi-dry, slightly smoky finish.  A good beer overall, right on style-wise.

Bottle split with Dallas. Pours a dark pitch black body with small brown lacing. Aroma is nice roasty characteristics and chocolate. The taste roatsy and bitter - not as delicious as the aroma suggests.

500 ml. bottle. Shared with Gabe. Pours an exuberant mocha head, with some lacing, over a dark black/brown (SRM 38) slightly cloudy body.....nose is coffee, cocoa, some grain....taste is coffee, cocoa, with heavy bitterness....mouth feel is medium, carbonation high. The bitterness from the roasted malts was out of balance with the rest of the ingredients. I wonder if the bottle was off, given the descriptions of other reviewers.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 TAP: very dark brown pour with reddish tones in the light. Small white head. Molasses on the nose, maybe some turpentine. Bitter cocoa taste, molasses, licorice. Good stuff.
Drank it with ghawener for dessert paired with Zebra ice cream.  Delicious, silky and smooth mouthfeel, creamy, nice malt backbone, flavors of chocolate and coffee.

500ml bottle from grape & gourmet. pours a deep, dark brown, damn near black with a half-inch, dark khaki head and great lacing. aroma is excellent with big, roasted dark malts, coffee, bitter chocolate, dried black cherry, figs, and a touch of smoke. flavor is simply outstanding with pure dark chocolate covered cherries and fresh, roasted coffee up front backed by big, roasted malts, fresh roasted almonds, vanilla, dried figs, and ashy, smoked wood leaving a lingering, bittersweet roasted/smoked finish. palate is full bodied, rich, and slightly sticky with moderated carbonation. overall, this one hell of a good porter, best ive had to date, and a bit underrated in my humble opinion.
500 ml bottle.  Pours super deep brown, almost black in colour.  Aroma is malty, smoky.  Taste is very strong, sweet, malty.  An excellent porter.  Loved it!
Bottle: Thanks to ramenen. Solid porter; had as dessert. Food Paring: Vanilla ice cream with fudge.
Bottle.  Nearly a black pour wtih a nice beige head.  Coffee, milk chocolate, roast and some very dark dried fruits.  Flavor is toasty and has a good chocolate backbone.  Fruity also.  Nice beer.

Pours black with reddish brown highlights, a thick light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, espresso coffee, bitter, dark chocolate, dried dark fruits. Nicely balanced flavour, much the same as the aroma, with some nuts, vanilla and vague smoke, with a nice hop bitterness in the finish, quite dry. Solid porter.

Dark tootsie roll/Coca Cola like in color with a thick tan head. Looks unfiltered when held before light. Im finding chocolate and espresso in the aroma along with some vanilla. Body is medium and only a bit oily. Nice roasted malt flavor that is really rounded out well. A liitle sweet and a little bitterness adds to the complexity with a reallt nice finish.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Bottle. Pours very dark ruby, nearly black, with a large, retaining light brown head. Aroma is full of roasted malt, coffee, vanilla and chocolate. Flavour is much the same as the aroma, without vanilla, but is very creamy, with a nice amount of bitterness. Mouthfeel is quite thick and creamy also and has a long-ish finish. A great porter in all respects.

A: Dark brown with a red hue. Not much light penetration. Big fluffy tan to light brown head. Had to let the beer settle a bit to fill the glass.

S: Lots of roasted malt, some dark fruits like plum and dark cherries, a little hop bitterness, some coffee and bitter chocolate.

T: Just like the smell lots of roasted malt flavors like coffee and chocolate. Slight bitterness but didnt take away from the balance of the beer. A bit of fruit but not so significant. As I drank more I picked up a pleasant smokiness which complemented the roasty notes quite well.

M: At times the alcohol was more present. Quite thick but not overly stout. Good creamy texture.

D: With the heavy body/mouthful I could prob only drink one bomber of this. This it a beer thats good for drinking with a nice burger or steak and savor the roasty complexity of the beer.

Had this on tap yesterday at Belmont Station in Portland, OR.  Colour... BLACK! With a 1/4 inch head.  Palate... cocoa mass, dark chocolate and light bodied coffee. Palate... somewhat thin mouthfeel, lots o coffee all over the palate, some chocolate, roasted malt and a medium dry finish.
Draught. Poured with very little head.   Malty and some fruit traces.  Pretty decent.
500ml bottle. Dark colored body. Roasted malt and chocolate coffee taste. Aromas of licorice, chocolate and vanilla.
Tap at Bergen bar. Cola like appearance, no head, slight bubbling. Slightly more chocolate than coffee in the aroma.

Bomber into a pint glass.  Pours almost black but brown when held to the light with a huge dark brown head.  Aroma is big coffee with some metal and lots of dark fruits.  A couple more whiffs reveal nice hop character.  The flavor is sweet and sour and ends with a nice combo 1-2 of dryness from hops and roasted malts.  This reminds of a good stout in many ways.  Quite tasty.

12.09.2009, 0,5l Bottle. Batch 406, Brewed 21.01.2009. This beer is black as tje night with tan head. Aroma is roasted dark malts. Very nice hoppy aroma and bitterness. This is a very good porter!!  ྦྷ.02.2004, 0,5l Bottle, Batch 14, brygget 19.07.2003. Ølet er svart med brunt skum. Ølet er preget av røyk/brent lukt og smak. Smaken er ellers preget av humle og bitterhet. Virkelig komplekst og sammensatt øl. Stor fylde og kropp. God balanse mellom alkohol og fylde)

A black colored beer, with a thick foamy dark beige head. The aroma of sweet chocolate, with some coffee and roasted malts. The taste of a little bitter chocolate with roasted malts and some dark fruits. The aftertaate is dry bitter with a little sweet.
Dark chocolate and toffee nose with charred oak undertones. Very dark brown pour with a medium tan head. Dry flavor of charcoal, strongly bitter, but tastefully so. Pretty boring overall.

It pours a dark, opaque sable with a VERY thick, if not too persistent, light brown head. The bottle I got foamed like nobodys business, so be careful if you have this in a bottle! Aroma is rich, smoky, mocha-like with a hint of sweetness, very inviting. Flavor is like fine roast coffee with chocolate undertones, but it got a bit tinny as I got near the bottom of the bottle. Texture is smooth and fairly tingly. Satisfying.

Serving: 16.9 oz. bottle.
Appearance: Almost black with garnet highlights and a huge, creamy, light tan head.  Great head retention and lacing.
Aroma: Lighter than expected nose.  Roasted malt, coffee, earth, and mineral notes.  A little difficult to get much else.
Taste: Sharp, upfront bitterness, roasted malt, a little caramel, mineral, nuts, and earth.  Sort of there then gone except for the bitterness.
Palate: Medium carbonation with a medium-rich mouthfeel and a medium, nutty finish.
Overall: A decent porter with a good palate, but muted aroma and flavor.
Rebuy: Worth trying but not rebuying.

Pours pitch black with a small tan head.
Aroma of dark roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee. Flavor is much the same, dark roasted malt, chocolate, a touch of coffee and some dark fruit. Malty chocolaty finish.
Pours very dark with a thin tan head to it. Smells like chocolate with some coffee and wood. Has a smokey chocolate flavor to it with a bitter finish. Not my style fo beer
Bottle. Pours with a black body and a tan head. Aroma of roast, leather and chocolate. Taste is leather, metal, chocolate and roast. Medium mouthfeel, light bubbles.

From the keg at Platform Bar, Brisbane. Pours very dark brown with a medium off white head. Rich dark chocolate, toast, mocha and dark fruit. Smooth mouthfeel and good bitterness. A nicely balanced porter. Big malty finish. My only problem is that one glass just isnt enough!

Dark brown with a big tan head. Roasted with coffe and chocolate tones.
malty with al ot of coffee. Medium to full body with a long bitter finish.

scura buona schiuma persitente ma grossolana note tostate torrefatte caffe cioccolato un po di luppolo fresco leggero dolciastro piuttosto morbida quoasi bilanciata ma con buon amaro persistente nel finale

My first Scandinavian rating!  Simple and attractive label.  Very nice pour - a big tan head comes billowing up from the black liquid.  A rich, sweet aroma with a bit of yeast and cheese.  Flavor is dry and fresh: some coffee, smoke, and tart and bitter hops.  There is something a little unusual too, like spruce or juniper or coriander.  Maybe it is just the Norwegian water (which I bet is excellent).  A very good dry porter.

500ml bottle.  Pours a near-black color with a relatively small tan head. Allowed to warm up slightly before consuming (not to 50, but closer), as consumed additional aroma and flavor stood out more. Aroma of sweet chocolates, lightly roasted malts, touch of coffee. Flavor is a bold, dark and milk chocolate with light malts flavor, with notes of coffee hidden in the rear. Finish is a Bitter finish, dark chocolates. A really wonderful beer, with a relatively low alcohol content for easy consumption.

Yay! Rare beer for me! The first of 21.5L of beer that I brought back from Las Vegas in my childrens luggage.

Dumped out a massive brown crown even with a soft pour. Super dark brown brew. Keeps a decent amount hanging around but leaves almost no lacing :( The aroma is pretty obvious early on but does fade: lots of chocolate, quiet coffee, good amount of roast and I can swear that I have found orange hiding far in the background. The taste is more coffee than chocolate when warm but that flips after awhile. Good bitterness with a slight citrus and leafy hop taste. Some nutty taste as well. Not much else there but that is irrelevant cause its just so damn drinkable. Smooth and higher than mid bodied; finishes dry and bitter. Pretty good. The down side - Ive got a quarter of a glass filled with sediment and in this case this beer is much much better clean.
Bottle. Black colour with large creamy light brown mostly lasting head. Aroma is roasted malt with notes of chocolate. Sweet flavor.

Nice dark pour with a dark brown head composed of 1000s of tiny bubbles. Roasted malt and chocolate aroma. Slight sweetness with nice roasted malt flavor. You notice the chocolate notes at the end of the drink. The aroma gets better as it warms-started at 45F.

Bottle. Very dark brown to near black pour. Short fading tan head. Aroma is dark chocolate, strong malt, light coffee notes, smoky notes and dark fruit. Taste is roasted malts, dark chocolate, bitter coffee, hop bitterness, lesser dark fruit notes, smoky wood and touches of melon. Body si medium-full and chewy. Strong carbonation notes as well. Ends with more chocolate, smoky/smoldering wood, cocoa, roasted malts, bitter, oily coffee, and hop notes. Melon comes through a bit towards the end as well. Very nice!
Bottle at 33. Roast. Chocolate. Our last beer of the night. Dark body. Very enjoyable. Pleasant finish.

"Very dark brown body almost zero light penetration. A thick rocky cap floats on top with stupidly long retention, lacing is awesome. Sweet/sour aroma lots of red wine and coffee, aroma is so bold. The more I think about it I know red wine isnt correct but thats all I can think of. The aroma is starting to get more spicy the longer it sits, possibly some apple showing up to. Smells so good. Lots of spicy earth in the taste, intense dirt (yes that is correct intense dirt) lots of coffee, possibly some cider. Mouth feel is smooth maybe a touch thin though. Flavour is blowing me away with its intensity. Tasting is turning more and more smoky as it warms. Im also getting possibly strawberry. So complex so yummy this an a amazing brew, Im positive I could drink this ten times and keep finding new flavours. By far the best beer you have brought back so far Jeff tanks olat."

This one was alright, it didnt have the chocolatey characters that I expect coming through so much, some coffee notes and a little burnt character, thin sometimes then not so and didnt notice it was 7% but I drank it easy and fairly enjoyed it.

Pitch black pour with boisterous tan head that is slow to dissipate, but leaves an enticing layer of foamy lacing. Aroma is far more roasty than your average porter. Smokey roast gives way to dark fermented raisin, coffee, caramel, and vanilla bourbon. Flavor mimics the aroma in many ways. Roasty components shine through vigorously. Malt character is very sweet, manifesting in the form of date, fig, raisin, molasses, and caramel. Coffee and chocolate also shine through to create a grandiose set of flavors. Palate is silky smooth with the most modest and caressing of carbonation. Finish is the sort of dryness that only comes from a serious roasted malt component. Overall, very impressive.

pours jet black with a pretty tan head- looks like an impy. Aroma is very roasty and smoky, but lots of dark fruit, caramel, and a bit of chocolate and coffee. Flavor is huuuge with coffee and chocolate, and a beautiful silky smoothness that i love and that you cant quite find in most stouts. Palate is luscious- damn good porter.

My first Nøgne, my first Norwegian (besides the last time I got some Aass, LOL!) - very refined and on the light side with a nice bit of sour yeastiness and smoky malt, and the expected coffee and mild chocolate. Pours very dark with an effusive but  light wheat-like tan head. I am getting raisin and fig type fruits, and a nice after-feel that is very pleasing, of hops and roast. Aroma is somewhat like flavor and a bit wild with some sour grains and barnyard. Would like some more rich toffee and chocolate in the middle to give it some legs. Almost lemony rather than sweet, The brew needs to find an anchoring point, but is a respectable Porter that might be good to session.

500ml bottle. Batch 396 Bottled 24.11.08 BB 24.11.13
Served with only a slight chill.

Pours a dense, medium-sized, tan head atop a near-opaque black body.

Big rich, bold malt aroma. Dark chocolate, strong milky coffee, toffee, dark and dried fruits, liquorice, rum. Hint of spice and herbaceous hop.

Body is beautifully creamy, almost velvet-like, moderate carbonation with a lengthy oily consistency. Astringencies are well rounded.

Plenty more dark chocolate and coffee on the body. Notes of date, nuts, sultana, and toffee. Finishes with a slight spice (possibly alcohol?), some bread and grain dryness, and a lingering bitter note.

Very nice porter indeed. Smooth, rich, satisfying, hard to fault.

Nice milk chocolate head with good strong carbonation aroma roasted chocolate coffee mild caramel very smooth flavour full roasted tastes chocolate coffee flavours are mellow with a vanilla and creamy note mixing with the malts hints of caramel body is good finish bitter creaminess

Bottle courtesy Yngwie.Creamy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. Dark amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. SLightly roasted and burnt. Moderate bitter flavor. Roasted notes. Average moderate bitter finisg. Oily palate.
bottle, dark brown color with good lasting tan foam, aroma of chocolate, nutty, light vanilla, flavor is medium chocolate, soy, missed the fruit, finish is weak for the style
Black colour with  a medium light brown head. Aroma and taste of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Nice palate.

The aging suprised me with this beer, the mouthfeel improved, the body seemed fuller and the taste had changed to mint chocolate like wonderful bew. I didnt care much for this before but I have to say now that this is pretty pretty good.

Dark pitch black color, with a tan colored head, roasted malt, black coffee nose with a dark chocolatey, roasted coffee bean accent, with a mild molasses, burnt dried dark fruity note of raisins, dates and plums, and a faint licorice spicy aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, molasses, roasted malt, dark chocolate character, with a black coffee, faint mochaish flavor, with a hint of licorice spiciness and burnt fruitiness leading towards a fruity, chocolatey, lingering roasted bitterness finish.
Roasted coffee and chocolate flavors. Really smooth. Dark brown pour with a brown head.

pitch black with a very attractive thick and creamy white head.  some hop and roasted notes to the nose.  moderate mouthfeel.  very nice flavor of some low crystal malt giving a nice sweetness with a lot of black patent character that makes the beer.  some hop bitterrness comes through and maybe a little citrusy hop flavor from the American hops.  a dry finish ends this very enjoyable robust porter.  very good version

25/03 0.5 l bottle my friend brought from Trondheim, fala lipa Dijo! My first Norwegian beer, strange but true. It poured a black body, actually brown dark as hell, with small brown head, maybe the darkest Ive seen on a beer! Coffee, caramel and some herbal spices dominate the aroma, but alcohol is felt as well. Fine flavor, dark malt shows up as a coffee with a bit of caramel. Slightly alcoholic. More subtle thing are starting to emerge while you drink it, as herbal spices and licorice, but I definitely miss some fruitiness to round it up, at least a little bit. Bitterish around the finish. Fine porter, but I still prefer our Tomislav to this.

Bottle. Pours black with a generous beige frothy head. Aroma of dark chocolate,coffee,raisins. Roasted malt and cold coffee notes in the mouth, some bitterness towards the end. Well balanced and enjoyable

Thanks retorp for the share.  Pours dark brown/ black with a nose of earthy coffee, dark fruit, vanilla, and some cherry?.  Flavor is roasted malt, ripe dark fruit, coffee, bitter chicory, up through the finish.  Very enjoyable porter that is medium-bodied and finishes clean and somewhat bitter.  Great porter.

courtesy of retorp
Pours black with beige head, some golden lacing.
Aroma malty, chocolate with light notes of coffee and dark raisins.
Taste was similar, chocolate malts, mild dark fruit presence, thick palate.
A fine porter.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Dark, dark, dark pour with a big head.  Definitely robust, which is how I like em.  Roasty as hell.  Some tobacco, some chocolate, plenty of awesomeness.  One kickass porter.

500 mL. Pours almost pitch black with a very thin, tan head. Leaves fairly good lacing. Aroma of raisins, dark chocolate, raw cocoa, molasses, spiced rum. Taste is creamy with rum raisin, dark chocolate, coffee with a harsh bite of warming alcohol and roasted nuts. 7% is not totally hidden. Ends a little dry and watery but this is a porter not a stout. Very powerful and enjoyable.

First beer poured into my new Pittsburgh Steelers Super Bowl Champions mug.  Pours a nice jet black color with a huge amount of froathy bubbly lighter brown head.  Reminds me of an irish coffee in appearance.  Aroma is actually rather weak: dark baking chocolate and molases.  Flavor is very light in general, molases and a bit of dry sweet chocolate.  Overall, not as good as Id hoped but not bad by any means.

0.5 l bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. GUSHED!
App.:  Deep brown black with a large, somewhat rocky light mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Lots of tangy black coffee, dark chocolate and molasses, vinous, slightly woody, very dark dried fruits, some sour cherries, black licorice.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, fairly lively effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Just like the nose  tangy black coffee and dark chocolate, a touch metallic, fruity and vinous, definite black licorice, thick and oily tasting; dry with slight tang and good bitterness with leftover roasted malts.

Pretty big for a Porter!

Pours a dark black with a large and bubbly dark brown head.  Aroma is sweet and has hints of coffee, dark malts, and chocolate.  The flavor is slightly sweet, with brown sugar, molasses, dark fruits, dark malts, and coffee.  The coffee gets stronger on the finish.  Very smooth beer.

[Sampled with the trio: Svoger, Svogergylp and Adenila Foged at EBF, 2008.] Although it is long time Ive tasted this I remember some great smoothness all over.  Good coffeechocs, sweetness and roasted malt. very pleasant and the best word describing this brew is: Soft!

Bottle at Novare.
Pours supremely dark brown not much light getting through this guy!  Aroma is super sweet, chocolate, coffee, and molasses.  Flavor is very nice upfront tastes like brown sugar and molasses, as it recedes it becomes a little more complex with a more bitter flavor of coffee and chocolate.  Super smooth mouthfeel.  This one is a very robust porter,  reminds me of baltic porters ive had...dare i say it almost could have an imperial in its name and i wouldnt bat an eye.

Bottle.  Pours pitch black with a big beige head, thick lacing.  Aroma is bar mocha and espresso.   Dark chocolate and malt with coffee and hops.  Creamy mouthfeel, smooth going down, alcohol barely noticeable.  Very nice, well balanced and enjoyable.

Cant see through this beer, or its beige head.  Light roasted malts, some chocolate, berries, nuts, and molasses.  Very nice.  Thick, creamy, and silky smooth.  Chocolate, toasted malts, faint dark fruits, some berries, molasses, and nutty.  Finishes with little dryness and some bittersweet chocolate.  This is one smooth, tasty, damn fine porter.  Heavy, but not like many "stouts" that masquerade as porters.  I should have bought three more... (Rating #800)

Pours a dark, opaque brown with a small tan head that deposits patchy lace on the glass. The nose is of chocolate, light coffee, faint almonds and roasted chocolate malt. Medium-bodied and creamy-slick with a mildly bitter and roasty finish. Sweet roasted chocolaty malt with a light almond and hop bitterness at the finish. A lingering coffee roastiness compliments the hops into the aftertaste. This is a fine porter. I really like this beer.
Pours deep brown with a thin tan head. Nose and flavor of smooth chocolate, roasted malt and coffee. Creamy on the palate.
UPDATED: OCT 5, 2009 Pours dark brown/black, roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate,little molasses, little nutty, slight licorice.
Bottle - poured dark in color with a tan head.  Hints of chocolate and coffee.  Medium to full bodied.  Another solid beer from Nogne.

1 pt. .9 fl. oz.  bottle in a pint glass.  Pours an immensely dark color, with a medium tan head.  The head dissipates quickly, but laces nicely.  Chunks of yeast are visible floating within the glass.  Yum.  It smells of malts, coffee, candied nuts, caramel, and figs.  It tastes of coffee, roasted malts, and very dark chocolate.  There is a nice, mild hop characteristic helping to balance the flavor.  Palate is thinner than expected, but not offsetting.

Pours a very dark brown with a full, light tan, creamy, somewhat rocky head; longevity is fair and some nice lace remains.  Nose is pleasant with fudge, light cocoa, moderate coffee roast, and hints at anise and dark dried fruit.  Flavor is good as well but more roasted, a bit stoutish; bitter chocolate, burnt fudge, light expresso, hints at molasses and anise, and a moderately high bitterness from both the roasting and the hops.  A bit more roasting than most porters, but certainly nice as a stout.  Palate is less than medium, watery, lively, and drying; my only complaint from the beer.  Finishes drying and mostly bitter with some burnt toast notes, expresso, and some rustic notes lingering; most of the sweet notes disappear by the end.  Not like most other porters with the use of more roasted malts but good nonetheless.  Somewhere between stout and porter.  With a better palate, this would be great.

Noire avec un court col café.
Parfum soutenu de caramel, tofee, houblon rôti.
Goût plutôt sucré. Très bon produit.
J’ai un souvenir lointain de cette dégustation. Ce fut agréable mais pas inoubliable...
Bottle.  Pours a black body with a tan head.  Roasty coffee, chocolate, caramel malt, light nuttiness, vanilla with sweet minerals to finish.

bottle thanks to KAggie.  shared at December Houston Tasting.  Pours black with a nice brown head and some good lacing.  Nose is funky with dried fruit and some roast malt.  taste is same with some chocolate.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin with carbonation and a bit harsh.  Not the best porter I have had.

Sample at the Hopsnobbery Collective Porter tasting at Dogbricks on 12/4/08.  Pours opaque dark brown with a small tan head.  Malty aroma with some roastiness and chocolate.  Smoky and roasty flavor, but not a whole lot else going on.

Bottle. Pours a nice black color with a medium tan head. Roasted malt in the aroma, as well as some chocolate in a hint of coffee. Nice balance in the aroma. Sweet taste. Some molasses and brown sugar. Light malt and some roasted coffee. One thing I will say is Nøgne is one of my favorite brewing companies. You know you get quality with them. And this is a solid porter.

Bottle from KAggie97 at the December Houston tasting.  I am gay for KAggie!  Pours a deep black with amber highlights and a nice beige head.  Smells like Pepto Bismol and melon.  Weird.  Flavor is blunt chocolate with cough syrup and a faint coffee finish.  Highly carbonated and fluffy mouthfeel.  Interesting.  Good for diahrrhea.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: (Draught at Pikkulintu, Helsinki, on 2008-12-05) Black. Small tan coloured head. Roastedness, chocolate and liquorice in nose. Dry and full bodied  palate with medium carbonation. Roastedness, liquorice, bitterness, some coffee, hint of sweetness and chocolate in taste. Roastedness and bitterness in dry aftertaste.

Pours with a dark brown to black body topped by a thin to medium thick head with a good amount of lacing.  It is slightly sweet yet slightly bitter with a light chocolate note and a touch of roast.  Full bodied, smooth and a touch warming.

Bottle thanks to kaggie at the RB Houston Impy Stout tasting. Pours black, with a small brown head. Opaque. Nose is chalky, coffee ish but not overwhelming. Very carbonated and fluffy, it sort of disappears in my mouth turning a liquid into a gas.  Very strange. Taste is a bit coffeeish with very little alcohol presence. Got better as it warmed but overall did not do much for me.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Best beer of the night at the Publick House near Boston.  Deep ruby-red medium-bodied porter with flavors of toffee and coffee, and a slightly smoky finish.  It tasted like a true British porter, whereas most American porters taste like stouts.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2009 Leave it to the Norsk to create such a good brew.  The best porter i have had since Samuel Smiths Taddy Porter.  Awesome smoked malt and roasty chocolate coffee taste.  Totally a bad ass beer.

Sample at the Hopsnobbery Collective Porter tasting on 12/4/08: This brew is a solid brownish-black color with a medium thin and rocky light brown head that dissipates steadily. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of smoked malt and dark chocolate plus a touch of coffee. Medium, round body with flavors of roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate and raisins. Light smoky character throughout. The finish is soft and roasty with a mocha aftertaste. Pretty good all around.
Great Porter.  Silky malt and wonderful body.  On a cold night, this is a sexy fireside share.

Black pour with a big, dense, tan head.  Lots of roasted malt aroma, dates, some semi-sweet chocolate, and a little blackberry.  Mixed and dark fruit flavors hit the tongue first followed by a nice balance of roast, coffee, and semi-sweet chocolate.  Medium body with gentle yet plentiful carbonation and a slightly aqueous finish.

bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  black pour with a thick rocky khaki head.  roasted malts, licorice, bitter sweet dark chocolate and dried fruits on the nose.  not as thick as i was expecting but a very smooth flavor of roasted malts up front with a coffee finish.

Poured from 550ml bottle into dimpled mug. Opaque brown in color with 1 finger creamy head. Aromas of dark malt, chocolate and coffee. Tastes of roasted malt,semi-sweet chocolate, and coffee. Excellent balance on the malt and hops. This a traditional porter at it’s finest. Unfortunately, at $8.99 per bottle it will have to be an occasional treat.

Bottle
Appearance: Deep black color, small but thick tan head,
Aroma: Dark mocca, roasted malt, coffee beans with a hint of dark berry´s 
Taste: strong coffee taste, dark chocolate, malt, dried black berry.
Really well balanced, my favorite Porter so far..

Holy cow, this is tasty.  Bottle; deep black pour with smallish and diminishing off-white head.  Bitter chocolate, sweet coffee, dried cherries and other dried fruits.  A touch of creaminess, but none of that sour porter thing.  Minor notes of peat and smoke.  Tons of roasty malt and a noticeable hop presence. This is a huge beer, but quite drinkable.  Fantastic.
Getting notebook online. Bottle. Pours a very inviting black. Nose very sweet caramel and chocolate flavors. They follow to the tongue with some hints of coffee. Very excellent porter!

From Wade’s Wines in SoCal.  Hey, if this is the porter, I can’t wait to taste the Imperial Stout because I hooked up several.  This one had a wonderful palate, smooth as can be coffee/fruit/choco-flavor, and superb maltiness.  This one’s an art, and it costs that to boot.

Batch 336, brewed 28.01.08.

Large, medium tan head. Pitch black, unpenetratable and shiny colour. 

A bit closed on the nose at first, but opens up after a while in the glass and the temperature rises a bit. Aromas of dark malts, raisins, chocolate, toffee and coffee with floral notes and hints of red berries and banana. 

Medium to full bodied and smooth on the palate with good, fine bubbled mousse. The coffee is more pronounced in the taste than on the nose. Finishes with a long, fresh, grainy bitter afertaste. 

Well balanced. Powerful, but still elegant. Wonderful porter!

Bottle Timfoolery aquired on trip to Southern California. Poured a dark brown with just a slight amount of a tan head. Definately tasted the coffee flavors thoughout the the entire beer experience. The roasted malts a brought out as the beer warms. Good beer!!

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2009 ap:pours dark brown, shows totally black in the glass, light brown head.
ar: coffee, chocolate, roasted stuff.
flavor: fruits, coffee, roasted stuff, well balanced, licorice.
palate is too bubbly.

Bottle from Vendome Liquors. Oil Black with small, tight, tan head. Aromas of dark chocolate and nice mellow coffee. Flavor follows with dark chocolate and coffee with a great blend of roasty malts with a very silky mouthfeel. The best Porter I’ve had to date.

I have been looking for this beer for some time.  Pours jet black with a nice but small tan head.  Aroma is plums and dark chocolate.  No roasted notes.  Flavor does have some roasted malt, caramel, milk, black licorice, dark fruit, and coffee.  Some nice hops as well.  It is nicely carbonated and both the roasted coffee beans and the hops can be tasted in the aftertaste that is a sweet roasted tart flavor.  I love a good porter and this is a good one.
Small head great nose.  Flavors of light rosted malts, chocolate, and toffee.  Medium palate wonderful brew.

Blackish slightly viscous pour with a finely beaded moussy brown head.
Bitter dark chocolate coffee and dried dates and figs in the note along with some bready notes
Taste: A very warm inviting rich blend of dark cocoa, espresso like notes dark dried fruits and some nutty flavors enveloped in a lightly silky package stopped from being too viscous with just a touch of chalkiness
Overall: What a wonderful beer - I just love the silky smooth textural component enveloping a lot of classic porter like notes. The best part being the dark malt flavors compliment and not dominate each other

black, small but firm film of head. Aroma of roasted nuts, roasted malt, coffe beans and something you would find at a burning fireplace. Taste is a bit hoppy, with tangling carbonation. Well balanced, long aftertaste of mocca, malts and hops. Very nice example of the style
Black; creamy tan head. Rich depth of dark malts. Dry, bitter, rich; creamy. A very excellent porter.
Good beer.  My 11th a beerfest.  I couldn’t find this beer booth at first.  I would towel off from the pool and have a Porter with cheese and crackers.

9/13/08 - Bottle courtesy/shared with Naka.  Pours black with thin, khaki head.  Nose is sugar and raisin, slight chocolate and caramel.  Fantastic oak and bourbon-esque character.  Taste is slight coffee and lits of chocolate, slight spicy notes.  a bit of oak and bourbon-y alcohol.  moderately watery mouth feel.  Chocolate and slight bitter finish.  Great porter.

Bottle at Nnudd tasting. Courtesy of Yngwie. Poured black with a medium beige head. In nose licorice and roasted malts. Medium bodied. It tastes like licorice, bitter chocolate and roasted malts. I thought it would be more complex but pretty good porter.

bottle.  deep brown pour with a big fizzy tan head that never goes away completely.  sweet coffee, bread and milk smells.  little thinner than I was expecting (for some unknown reason) - but still had a chewy quality to it.  tastes of dark fruits, toasted malts, dark chocolate and soy.  interesting.  not sure I’ve had a porter like this before. probably more complex than any I’ve had before - but maybe wouldn’t be dying to try again.  K-8

[EBF @ Copenhagen, September 2008] Cask condition porter. Small rocky beige head. Dark mahogany color. Aroma of mild wood, chocolate, coffee, hint of smoke. Medium to full bodied with a soft carbonation and mild dry quite smooth texture. Moderated sweet and bitter flavor in balance. Lingering smooth malty finish. Very drinkable.

(Bottle).  Aroma is slightly hoppy, some coffee and citrus.  Black, with gargantuan thick fluffy brown head.  Delicious flavor profile.....chocolate, malt, caramel, a touch of roastiness.  Lengthy bitter finish.  Wonderfully delicious.

Pours dark black color with a thick foamy beige head that disappears after a few seconds.  The aroma is a sweet brown sugar and raisin with some whiskey notes to it.  Has a deep malty coffee flavor with an almost bourbon aged flavor to it.  I’m not sure if it is.  The body is pretty creamy.  As it warms, the coffee flavors come out more.  It leaves a nice chocolaty bitter in the finish.  An excellent porter.

Cask at EBF 2008.
Black with a beige head. Aroma heavy malty (roasted, burnt, coffee, dark fruit) Flavor heavy sweet and bitter. Medium body.
Black colour with medium beige head.Aroma is light smoked and flavor of coffee and rosted caramel feels well balanced and and nice wice soft finish.
bottle.  black pour with a mottled brown and tan head. big roasted malt nose with coffee and choclate.  Flavor is bitter, coffee and cacao again.  Fullbodied and really well done.  Great porter.

Bottle.  Black in color, medium thick brown bubbly head.  Moderate nutty and roasty aroma, mild chocolate background notes.  Taste is a mix of roast and chocolate, light coffee, the roast is on the sweeter side.  Well balanced and quality.

Aroma of roasted coffe, and dark, sweet fruit.  The apopearance is dark brown, with a purple tinge.   The flavor is roasty to be sure, but with a steady component of fruity sweetness.  The surprise here is the finish, it has a nice bite from hops which didn’t make themselves evident previously.  Great porter.

Bottled 50cl. It pours a pitch black beer with a full beige head. Good head retention. Some nice lacework. Sweet nose which is mainly of pumpernickel and roasted malt accompanied by grapefruit. The taste is of roasted malt, pumpernickel and rose. Sweet. Some tar and licorice showing up. Good bitterness. Nicely balanced. The finish is rather pleasant with hints of pumpernickel, grapefruit, syrup and rose. Thanks a lot larsga for this beer!
Small head on a black body. Plums and cocoa aroma. Roasty espresso, cocoa, bitter chocolate with light milky sugary sweetness. Medium body. Enjoyable.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2010 Bottle from Cracked Kettle. Dark brown/black colour, beige head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and roasted malts, a bit musty. Flavour is bitter, roasted malts and strong coffee, some dark chocolate, slight sweetness. OK porter, but expected a bit more. 637415 Re-rate Bottle sample at stout tasting at In de Wildeman. A lot more dark and dried fruit notes, nice sweetness, chocolate. Highly enjoyable. 738416

Deep brown in color with a moderate head.  The nose shows hoppy aromas of chocolate and coffee beans.  In the mouth it is on the hoppy side which comes off as light-on-its-feet.  I would prefer a bit more mid-palate concentration and flavor but this is well made and balanced.

Bottle.  Pretty much black with a decent brown head although without much lacing.  Aroma is dark roasty malt, chocolate, and coffee.  Lovely mild sweetness and goes down very smooth with a slightly dry aftertaste.  Very good.

Pours a murky dark espresso brown with a lovely light creamy tan head.   Sweet molasses aroma, bakers chocolate and lots of fresh hops.   Rich chocolate, condensed milk, floral hops, a bit vinous and nutty, light coffee and molasses, complex and definitely Nogne.   Medium/light body with silky tingling carbonation.   Easy drinking Porter that could easily be a Brown Ale.    Really a well done brew.

Bottle, batch 269. Black colour with a small brown head. Aroma is sweet and coffee with hints of liquorice. Strong, bittersweet, coffee, dark chocolate and liquorice taste. Oily and quite full-bodied. Dry, long and roasted mouthfeel. An excellent porter.
Bottle:  Pours a black oily pour with a thin ring of white head.  Very sweet, and smooth, this is packed with creamy chocoalte malt and sugars.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: Tasted 7/24/08.  500ml bottle.  Dark brown and thick.  Finger width of beige head.  Toffee aromas with hints of cocoa, toast and mild anise.  Solid nose!  Rather full bodied with a sticky malt character.  Coffee and bittersweet chocolate flavors.  Cookies and dark berries.  Sticky with a mild tart and bitter palate.  Decent hop palate.  Mild vanilla creaminess.  Mild raisin note.  Good rolling palate, but on the sweet side.  Low effervescence and mild acidity.  Almost a Baltic style, but hoppier.  Totally tasty!
almost black, little caafe au lati head. Strong notes of burned malt, liquorice,  dark chocolate, and coffee. Sweet and bitter in great balancce. bitter finish. creamy soft mouthfeel.

Delicious. Tried this one after a disappointing left hand milk stout. Full, rich, slightly acidic. Chocolate, smoke, and a bit of bitter fruit is present throughout. Slightly harsh, and a surprising amount of hop for a porter. Overall, a wonderful brew. If it ever costs less than $11 a bottle, I’ll buy more.

Smells and taste like it has oatmeal in it, which is OK. Dry palate. Didn’t get much fruity flavors Without a doubt a good solid porter but I was expecting more. Got another bottle so maybe that one will floor me.

Pretty good. Roasted malt flavor with more chocolate than usual, not very sweet which was good. Dryer taste than most porters I have had. Very drinkable. Did not taste any alcohol. Nice bitter finish. Surprisingly light bodied for the dark color and alcohol content.

Bottle. Black pour with ruby hightlights. Slowly diminishing tan head. Aroma displays malts  roasted grain, chocolate, nuts and a hint of hops, particuarly  pine. Hints of chocolate and coffee. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. However, it finishes up moderately bitter and moderately acidic and leaves hints of smoked peat and roasted malts. Wonderful creamy texture and medium body. Lively carbonation. Smooth, clean, nicely bittered porter with pleasant, somewhat complex aroma and lots of flavor.

Dark brown pour, tan head.  Roasty and earthy in scent and flavor, just a hint of mocha.  Great in the mouth and smooth going down.  Lingers nicely a bit, but clean.  Side note, Scandanavian porters are the best, close second English, then US.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle, gift from Mes. Little coffee, smoke, dark choloate hints. Well balanced and not over powering in any department. Really nice, fine porter.

Sample courtesy of piscator- very rich pouring brew. Nose- lots of roast and dark chocolate.  Taste- dry, little smoky, good roast and medium bodied.  Carbonation is on low side which improves drinkability.

375ml bottle LooseCannon was kind enough to split with me. Black as they come with a brown head.Toasty, chocolate cocoa like nose, a splash of coffee. Body is thick, seems a bit flat. Rich chocolate flavors, sweet, a hint of vanilla and a light floral bite. Very good!

Appearance: Very dark brown. Nice amount of head, and not short-lived.
Aroma: Smokey, oaky, and malt. Coffee.
Taste: Malty. Bitter. Smokey. Pretty bitter aftertaste. Dry.
Info: 500ml bottle, 10/1-2007
6/29/08: Bottle. Dark brown-black body accompanied by a rich tan head.  Spotty lace - creamy too.  Chocolate stout malt nose.  Coffee flavors with lots of black patent and crystal malt.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Opaque black with a medium tan head. Prominent roasty mocha nose, very nice. Mmmm very deep, roasty rich chocolaty flavor with the perfect amount of caramel sweetness underneath. Very well balanced with a little citrus hop note in there. Not astringent or bitter. The takeaway flavor is caramel chocolaty goodness. Alcohol content very well hidden. Doesnt have a thick body like some stouts; more like classic medium/light porter body with soft carbonation. Very flavorful and drinkable. Highly recommended.
16.9oz bottle. Pours pitch black in color with brown head. Aroma chocolate and coffee. Taste of dark chocolate, roasted malt and coffee with bitter finish.
Pretty nice porter. Molasses, very slight cocoa powder. This doesnt seem to be the most complex of beers, but its not simplistic and its pretty darn tasty.

50cl bottle from KIngdom Liquors (Tampa, FL). Aroma is dark malt, ripe dark fruit, coffee, dark chocolate, molasses. Flavor is dark chocolate, toffee, coffee, heavy malt, sugar. Medium to heavy-bodied with a lingering chocolate-coffee finish. Nice porter.

Bottle. Completely black color, low tan head. Aroma of resiny hops and black soil. Wickedly smooth mouthfeel and a taste with  plenty of chocolate and black patent malt. Very drinkable and very tasty!
Bottle @ Balsam Cocktail Lounge Oslo, Norway. Pitch black and sirupy with thick foam. A bit weak on the aroma compared to the great taste. Otherwise a GREAT porter!

Thanks to a great bartender at Philadelphias Eulogy Tavern I had a bottle of this great porter.  Pours a dark midnight brown and supports a thin but dense and long lasting light brown head with solid curtains of lacing.  Roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate, and toffee in the nose with the same in the flavors.  Some cocoa and vanilla along with enough hops to provide a nice bitter overtone as well.  Smooth and velvety texture and a dry finish with a little peppery alcohol popping out at the end.  If other brewers in Norway turn out this kind of quality, I might have to add their stamp to my passport.

Straightforward but solid porter.  Poured black with average head that was not sustained. Nice lacing.  Aroma of dark fruits and chocolate, although not too much aroma.  Flavor of choclate, malit with a little hop dryness at the end.  Not overly complex.  Smooth full bodied taste.  Reallly nice porter.

Bottled sample consumed with oakbluff. Near black in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas of dark chocolate, coffee, and red grapes. Very roasty and dry in the mouth, but it doesnt sacrifice too much in terms of malt presence or body. Very drinkable for 7% ABV, with a long roasted malt finish. Very good indeed.

Bottle.  First thing is that as I pop the cap there is a fizzy whoosh, but then nothing good or bad really comes of it... flavor is fine, floor isnt covered in foam, nothing.  Anyhow, pour is a dark brown with only about a half inch of head... in spite of the aforementioned sound.  Aromas are light chocolate and dark fruit, but fairly faint.  Flavor is heavily cocoa with some dark malt.  That said, things dont fully blossom as it is kind of unidimensiona.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 1/2 litre bottle courtesy of and shared with Maniac. Black with a medium tan head. Big roast malt aroma with some coffee, raisin and molases. Roast malts dominate flavor with some raisin, coffee, and earthy hops and a moderate astringency. Finish is dry with a bit of lingering bitterness. Excellent.

Dark brown body with light ruby highlights, and a large creamy tan head. Chocolate and roasted malt aroma with some caramel hints. Big roasted malt flavor with chocolate notes and more faint caramel and light molassas and a reasonable bitter finish. Medium body with moderate carbonation and a smooth chocolately finish.
Black beer. Thick brown head. Roasted malt nose with a hint of chocolate. Chocolate taste up front. Huge building roast flavour. Sharp aluminum chocolate finish.
Bottle - I found this beer to be quite nice.  Bready/raisin aroma with chocolate malt, burnt coffee and raisin flavor.

500 ml bottle. Deep dark brown, creamy beige head. Roasted malts, dark chocolate and coffee in the aroma. Flavour is coffee, dark fruits, nuts and roasted malts. Ashy, a bit smoky aftertaste. An excellent porter.

16.9 oz. into pint glass.  Pitch black pour with great creamy espresso, long-lasting head with very nice cascade effect as head and body settle into each other.  Typical porter/stout aromas - coffee, molasses, milk chocolate, etc. - with a sweet vanilla undertone; very well rounded and complex and delicious aroma.   Flavor is rich and full with all aromas included, most notably chocolate.  Very soft and smooth on taste buds (like on palate) with no rough or offensive edges.  Overall: one of the best porters I have ever had; not watery on palate like many other non-imperial porters (some ratings disagree though).

Lots and lots of raisin flavors, stewed fruit make this a much heavier beer that I expected.  I have never really loved the raisin and prune characteristics of dark malts and cant say that this beer has turned me on to them.

BOTTLE: served cool.  Dark with nice quick head.  Aroma is definitely fruity and enticing but not very strong.  Flavor is unexpected fruitiness combined with the coffee and dark malt, with a bitter finish.  A most surprising porter with features unlike any other Ive had.  Palate is nice and medium length.

50 Cl Bottle-Black pour w/a trace of Mahogany. Moderate tan head. Standard porter flavor, maybe a little more coffee than anything else, a little light on the chocolate. Had a little bite to it, I prefer mine a little smoother. Mouthfeel was kind of thin. Solid brew, but I was honestly a little disapointed what with all the buzz on these beers.

50 cl bottle on 5/19/08. Dark brown with mahogany highlights and a large, creamy, and persistent light tan head. Inviting coffee and chocolate aroma accented with roasted nuts and a bit of earthiness. Medium to full body and light carbonation match up well with a creamy smooth mouthfeel. Molasses sweetness subsides slowly, ultimately giving way to a gentle spicy bitterness. Wonderful balance in this fine porter. Very drinkable, highly recommended.

Bottle from somewhere in North Carolina. Pours cola brown with a medium head. Good retention, moderate lacing. Nice roasty, mocha aroma. Taste is a little lighter than I expected, but what is there is good... roasted malt, coffee, nuts. Creamy feel.

50cl bottle from Vinmonopolet, batch 269. It poured a black body with a dark creamy head that vanished very quickly. It tastes of coffee, toffee, apples and raisins. It expands in your mouth and the aftertaste lasts a long time.

Pours a deep opaque dark brown color with a medium tan creamy head. Nose is pleasant with lots of coffee character, chocolate and black malt. IMouth feel is thin and light. Initial taste creamy coffee ice cream persay. Melts in your mouth coffee. Mildly hopped that balances well. Deep richness of the black malt giving off that mild burnt taste with chocolate malt hindering in. Finishing with the continuing coffee and black malt. Average palate duration. Head retention is good with thick sheets of the lacing that slaps the walls of the glass beautifully. Light to medium body and very easy drinking. Simple but delicious.
Poured a very dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is mostly of coffee and some caramel.  Taste is also mainly coffee but a bit watery for my expectations.

Pours black with a creamy tan head. Nice aroma of coffee and roasted malt. Good roasted coffee flavor that lingers nicely. A little too weak on the body in my opinion. Really close to being great but not quite there.

Pours a very dark brown with a tall and thick light brown head. Fantastic aroma of coffee and sweet roasted caramel malts. Mouth feel is very smooth and creamy. The initial taste is very sweet, a little bit of nutty chocolate. The finish is a lightly caramelized coffee bean. Very delicious aftertaste to a well balanced beer.

Bottle.  Pours very dark black with a medium beige head.  Aroma is filled with dark malts--chocolate, coffee, caramel, with some dark fruit and nut smell.  Flavor is similar, lots of chocolate, coffee roastiness, some smoke even.  Bittersweet finish from malt.  Delicious.

Poured from a bottle was a pretty dark brown beer with a good tan head. Nice aromas of sweet chocolate roasty malt. Pretty pleasantly smooth in your mouth. A little carbonation and good chocolate cofee like flavors. Good finish for a porter. Pretty solid beer.

Hadnt really expected much with this and was really suprised to find out how dry the beer was. There was really very little sweetness left, just a lot of ashy/roasted notes that I didnt find all that enjoyable. The beer looked great though. A nice thick black liquid with a creamy tan foamy head. Aroma smelled a lot like coffee too, with some dark chocolate notes too. I know Im unabashed in my love of stouts, especially those on the sweeter side of things. This beer was clearly on the other end of the spectrum. But still, I did enjoy the beer and would get it again.

50 cL bottle. Pours black with a dense light brown head. Roasted malt and chocolate aroma. Promise of a roasted and hops bitter flavour. Flavour is mild tar, light smoked, roasted malt and smooth chocolate following. Very smooth with liqourice added along the way. Light roasted bitterness following into a chocolate and roasted malt bitter finish. Very nice. One of the pre-RB beers I finally get to rate. Perfect for boiling vegetables in the owen, carrots for instance. Seriously!

Pour was jet black with minimal head and lacing.  Nice aroma of chocolate and roast with vinous notes.  The flavor was rich chocolate and dark fruits with hints of roast and coffee.  Really nice thick milkshake like mouthfeel.  This was quite enjoyable, even if I had to sell my kids off for medical experimentation to pay for the bottle.

*liked it ok, would not buy*

aroma: smokeyness, wet dog, rich black malts. app: black! yum flavor: very smokey, a lil burnt. rich nice not to bitter. clean finish. lotsa smoke. palate: to thin. OA: its good, not great. i wanted more richness less sour/smoke

16.9oz bottle.  On point stuff.  The aroma is spot on, chocolate and roasted malt scents all the way.  Deep opaque black color.  The malt character just shines with this beer.  Super well-balanced and full bodied porter, while remaining completely drinkable.  Chewy and big,  one of the best porters out there.

Bottle. [thank you, faroeviking]
Pours black with slight brown edges. A big, dense, creamy, light-brown head. Great duration. Aroma is sweet, good chocolate, some roastiness. Softly carbonated with a general nice creaminess - but seems a little thin. Flavour has lots of sweet, fat chocolate with a good roasted coffe note in the aftertaste. Some bitterness as well. Good porter!

bottle from west lakeview......pours dark brown with reddish brown edges.  very thin soapy beige head.... aroma of roasted chocolate malt and maybe a little dark fruit but very little.... flavors of smoky chocolate malt with medium carbonation and body....i dont have a whole lot to say about this one im afraid....not a bad porter but far from being a special one.
Very black. Aroma is quite normal, a bit malty. The flavor is strong at first with some hops in the finish. A basic porter i.e. very drinkable.

Pours a pitch black with a brown foam head with poor retention and some lacing with a wonderful chocolate aroma. Tastes dry and quite reserved, light notes of smoke, good hoppiness, warm and dry with an astringent, woody finish. Creamy but pinched (thin) body, passable carbonation. Very subtle, pleasant beer, well executed but not too adventurous.

(Bottled 10/2006) Black with light, tanned head. Nose is strong dark chocolate and soft burned malts. Flavor has liquorice and dark fruits. Finishes with coffee, chocolate and smoothly herbal bitterness. Medium bodied, round and a bit oily palate. Rich and satisfying, without being that heavy.

Black Pour. Fairly large and growing head. Aroma of cocoa,coffee a tad of licorice.
 Taste is similar to aroma. One of the better porters Ive had tho Ill admit the style is down on my list.

500 ml bottle. Black, almost pitch black, but there are some reddish hues. Thick beige and grey head that clings to the glass. Chocolatey aroma that leans towards cocao powder. Grassy hop aroma. Piney hop flavours and crisp carbonation balances a rich chewy chocolate flavour. Malty, but not really sweet, likely because of the amount of hops used. Bitterness lingers a long time together with oily chocolate. Delicious.

500ml bottle. Pours black with a crisp tan head that fades quick to nothing. Smells roasty and ashy/burnt. Also smells dark and fruity sweet. Tastes sweet and roasty, raisins and dark fruit. Medim body with good carbonation and a pretty dry mouthfeel.
Black with huge brown head. Sweet aroma with notes of chocolate, coffee and roasted malt. Same goes for the flavor that ends slightly bitter.

500 ml bottle.  Pours dark brown/black with a medium sized diminishing tan head.  The aroma is a little subdued but includes roasted malt and semi sweet chocolate.  The flavor leans heavily to the roasted malt side, but also includes semi sweet chocolate, a touch of dark fruits, and a hint of licorice and vanilla.  Maybe a touch thin, but very good otherwise.  Could serve as a solid warmer weather dark beer.

What a taste. Beautifully smooth malty aroma with a hint of smoke, coffee, biscuits, raisins, salty liquorice, dark chocolate... Aftertaste is long, turns on the slightly sweet side. Another great beer from Norge.

500ml Bottle- Black in colour with a tan head. Liquorice and coffee featuring in the mildly alcoholic aroma. Aniseed and liquorice in the taste which is balanced with coffee and a very slight sour hint to the finish. Not bad at all.

yummy bottle at ethereals. Raspberry, medicinal herbs, seaweed, toasted malt, tar black, brown stable head, camphor, roasted barley, bitter, salty liquorice sweets, smooth, expertly balanced, yummy stuff.- this is honestly what my notes looked like! a bit of a mess but i did really like it :-)

Thanks to my secret santa for this.  Pours black with a modest, long-lasting tan head.  Aroma is distinctly "Nogne" with a sort of burnt caramel, mineral heavy water, leaves, roast, chocolate, raisins...pretty versatile aroma when warm.  When cold, its kinda meh.  Tastes more normal though, some roast astringency, dirt, minerals, coffee, finishing with a pleasant roasty aftertaste, a little lactose as the beer gets swallowed.  Medium palate, easy drinking, fairly well carbonated.  Its alright.

Pours a nice black color with a tan head.  Roasted aroma with coffee and some chocolate.  Tastes of predominantly roasted malts with coffee and dark chocolate.  Well-balanced, creamy with just a hint of carbonation.

Pours an opaque, black body with foamy, tan head.  Aroma of cocoa, malts, yeast, bread, and some hops.  Flavor initially is dark fruit, but then gives way to a strong dark roasted malt taste with cigar smoke.  The dark fruit character tends to come out more as the beer warms.  Medium-bodied, but comes off slightly watery.  Smoke and coffee aftertaste.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2008 Thanks to zeke626 for sharing. The beer was opaque black/brown almost motor oilish, generous amount of light brown head. Mild hops and faint chocolate malt were present in the aroma. I tasted fairly bold burnt malt (but not charred) with the faint presence of sugar and alcohol. The hops were almost non-existent. As it warmed I began to get more alcohol and the taste of sweet dark fruit at the start of the beer. Smooth, not too heavy on the palate. A very solid porter!

Bottle. About one year old from cellar. Pours beautiful plum black with smallish light brown head. Aroma: Coffee, dark fruits, roasted malts yum! Wonderful creamy texture with light carbonation on the back of my tongue. Bitter hop finish.

500ml bottle, 28th Feb 2008. Pours pure black with a tan head. Aroma of medicinal herbs and toasted malt, with coffee and fruity hints. Great aroma of dark roasted malt, camphor, salty liquorice and bitter chocolate and coffee. Perfectly smooth as it goes down. Great stuff!

Poured black with a dark brown head. Aroma - Coffee, malt and dark fruit. A lot of dark chocolate up front with some dark fruits - raisins and plums - notes of roast malt, coffeee and a touch of bitterness.
Dark brown pour with a thick tan head. Big coffee aromas, along with hops. Flavor is licorice, coffee and roasted malts. Very enjoyable.

Bottle at patrick767 gathering. Small tan head that mostly diminished, no lacing, opaque, very little carbonation, and a black hue. Nose was malty, caramel, roasty and hoppy. Flavor was malty, roasty, coffee, and some dried fruit. Smooth mouthfeel and medium body. Very quaffable, definitely worthy of a try and I would definitely drink this one again if it were to come my way. Quite tasty indeed and nicely done.

Opaque black with a generous tan head. A strong aroma of coffee, roasted malt and chocolate. Medium bodied, slightly oil-like feel - and look, hehe - to it. Roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee and liquorice appear in the taste. A pleasant porter - tried it with cheese as they advised, sgood!

Extremely well crafted brew.  Not a very strong aroma but taste hints of chocolate, berries, roasted nuts with a slight carbonation.  Not of the flavors are right up front and very balanced.  No Alcohol in sight here.  Very good.  Looking forward to the Nogne Imperial Stout.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle. Pours a pitch black color, with very prominent marshmallow-like tan head. Leaves tons of gorgeous lacing. An awesome beer just to stare at and appreciate. Aroma has some soft malts, licorice, caramel, and a nice underlying roasty quality. Rich sugars and fruits in the flavor; some caramel, roasted coffee, dry molasses. Pretty good. Smooth and velvet-like body. Incredibly easy to drink.

Bottle.  Coffee colored pour with a tan head.  Malty aroma - roasty, smoky, nuts, light wood.  Really well balanced flavor - hops and good roasted malt character.  Great palate.  Overall, one of the better porters that Ive had.

bottle.  Aroma has notes of resin hops, roasted malt, and yeast.  Above average sized tan head that mostly diminished and left no lace.  Black hue.  Flavor has caramel, coffee, chocolate, and yeast.  Palate is medium bodied and smooth.  A little off in places but average.

bottle - pours jet black with some thickness and chocolaty head; aromas of grain, dates and some coffee; decent body thats well above the all to common watery porter; drinks with flavors of coffee and molasses; very nice

Bottle from Marcus - Thanks! Interesting aromas of toasted malt, chocolate, reddish fruits, and perhaps a bit of coffee. Opaque brown/black color with a beige/tan head thats respectable. Medium body with smooth frothy carbonation. Flavors are sharp burnt malt, coffee, chocolate, hop bitter and more. The finish is dry, and a bit muddy as the flavors intermingle. Decent amount of burnt toast and bitter. Really good to drink.

dark violet black color with small brown head. chocolate berry aroma with a light spicy mocha note. smooth soft body. deep chocolate, blackberries, and currant flavors.  there is a very small roasted coffee undertone. it has a bitter sweet spicy finish. delicious brew, fruity and warming.
